com.tencent.tcr.sdk.api

Interface Mouse


  • public interface Mouse
    Cloud mouse interaction APIs, which can send mouse button events to the cloud. You can also use onDeltaMove(int, int) and onMoveTo(int, int) to move the cursor on TcrRenderView.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void onDeltaMove(int deltaX, int deltaY)
      According to the offset pixel amount of the local mouse movement [deltaX, deltaY], calculate the relative movement pixel amount [remoteDeltaX, remoteDeltaY] of the remote movement.
      void onKey(MouseKey key, boolean down)
      Trigger a click event of the cloud mouse.
      void onMoveTo(int x, int y)
      After you get the coordinates of the local View, you need to convert the coordinates to the coordinates of the remote end before calling this method.First, you need to calculate the coordinates according to the ratio of the local and remote device display screen, and then add the coordinates to the offset of the remote window before calling.
      void onScroll(boolean down)
      Rotate the scroll wheel of the cloud mouse.
      void setCursorStyle(CursorStyle cursorStyle)
      Set the cursor style.
      void setMouseInfoListener(MouseInfoListener mouseInfoListener)
      Set up a listener to get information about the mouse.

    • Method Detail

      • setCursorStyle

        void setCursorStyle(CursorStyle cursorStyle)
        Set the cursor style. The cursor style CursorStyle will be updated immediately: the new cursor style will be distributed from the cloud through the data channel. You can get the latest mouse style image from MouseInfoListener.
        Parameters:
        cursorStyle - The new cursor style, which will overwrite the original style value.

      • setMouseInfoListener

        void setMouseInfoListener(MouseInfoListener mouseInfoListener)
        Set up a listener to get information about the mouse.
        Parameters:
        mouseInfoListener - MouseInfoListener object

      • onKey

        void onKey(MouseKey key,
           boolean down)
        Trigger a click event of the cloud mouse.
        Parameters:
        key - The mouse button. Valid values: `left`: The left button; `middle`: The scroll wheel; `right`: The right button; `forward`: The forward side button; `backward`: The back side button.
        down - Valid values: `true`: Press; `false`: Release.

      • onScroll

        void onScroll(boolean down)
        Rotate the scroll wheel of the cloud mouse.
        Parameters:
        down - Valid values: `true`: Scroll down; `false`: Scroll up.

      • onDeltaMove

        void onDeltaMove(int deltaX,
                 int deltaY)
        According to the offset pixel amount of the local mouse movement [deltaX, deltaY], calculate the relative movement pixel amount [remoteDeltaX, remoteDeltaY] of the remote movement. You can refer to the following sample code to complete your own calculations. You can refer to TcrEvent.EVENT_REMOTE_DESKTOP_INFO for the parameters of the remote device 
        
      // calculate the remote movement pixel
      remoteDeltaX = remoteViewWidth/localViewWidth * localDeltaX * MouseConfig.getMoveSensitivity();
      remoteDeltaY = remoteViewHeight/localViewHeight * localDeltaY * MouseConfig.getMoveSensitivity();
      // send mouse move message
      onDeltaMove(remoteDeltaX,remoteDeltaY);
        Parameters:
        deltaX - The offset on the horizontal axis by which the cursor needs to move in remote device
        deltaY - The offset on the vertical axis by which the cursor needs to move in remote device

      • onMoveTo

        void onMoveTo(int x,
              int y)
        After you get the coordinates of the local View, you need to convert the coordinates to the coordinates of the remote end before calling this method.First, you need to calculate the coordinates according to the ratio of the local and remote device display screen, and then add the coordinates to the offset of the remote window before calling. You can refer to the following sample code to complete your own calculations. You can refer to TcrEvent.EVENT_REMOTE_DESKTOP_INFO for the parameters of the remote device 
        
      // first step: Calculate the coordinates of the remote app window according to the scale
      remoteX = remoteWidth/localWidth * localX;
      remoteY = remoteHeight/localHeight * localY;
      // second step: Add the offset of the cloud window to get the exact coordinate position of the remote device
      remoteX = remoteX + screenLeftOffset;
      remoteY = remoteY + screenTopOffset;
      // finally: send mouse move message
      onMoveTo(remoteX,remoteY);
        Parameters:
        x - The X coordinate on the remote device
        y - The Y coordinate on the remote device
